answers.body_markdown:
The issue here is with the line breaks in your ```cellRendererFramework``` and ```icons``` attributes, since JSON does not support literal line breaks. If you intend to keep those attributes as strings (rather than turning the ```icons``` attribute into another object), you could try the following:

```
[ 
   { 
      "headerName":"",
      "field":"",
      "headerCheckboxSelection":true,
      "checkboxSelection":true,
      "width":45
   },
   { 
      "headerName":"A-1 PORT",
      "width":110,
      "cellRendererFramework":"params => { return this.renderCells(params) }",
      "field":"a1Port",
      "tooltipField":"A-1 PORT",
      "icons":"{ sortAscending: `<img src=${ascArrow} style=\"margin-left:65px;color:black; position:absolute\" />`, sortDescending: `<img src=${dscArrow} style=\"margin-left:65px;color:black; position:absolute\" />`}"
   }
]
```

If you want to preserve the line breaks in your string, you can insert ```\n``` wherever you want a line break.

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

answers.body_markdown:
As I pointed out in comments, most probably some of the files being sorted are modified during the sorting. Then, what was initially an old file becomes a new file _during_ sorting, thus the ordering relation 'is newer' appears non-transitive, which breaks the contract; hence the error.

IMHO you can only write your own sorting routine, which would handle such non-transitivity safely. For example it can reiterate when it detects the situation. But take care not to iterate too many times - if two or more files get updated constantly, the re-sorting routine could never finish its work!

answers.body_markdown:
According to the documentation link you provided:

> `select` returns a list of `gribmessage` instances.

So, when you do this:

    grb1=grbs.select(name='Geopotential Height')[0:24]

You are taking the result of `select` (which is a list), and then slicing that list (which yields another list). The sliced list is then bound to `grb1`. Therefore, grb1 is a list of `gribmessage` instances.

As the Pyhton exception states, a list does not have a `values` attribute. However, a single `gribmessage`, presumably, does.

Not sure if this gets you closer to the result you're expecting, but you can use a list comprehension to get the `value`s from the `gribmessage` instances in your list:

    values = [grb.values for grb in grb1]

items.body_markdown:
We are working on remodeling our user phones to separate (on the frontend) the selection of the phone international code prefix and the number without prefix.

But on the backend side, we are only storing a "normalized_phone" using the `Phony` gem

Assume an incoming payload that may contain several attributes

```json
{ user: {
  international_prefix: '+33',
  number_without_prefix: '42424242',
  last_name: 'xxx'
} }
```

and its model

```ruby
class User
  field :normalized_phone # includes both international_prefix and number_without_prefix
  field :last_name

  validate :last_name, ...
  validate :normalized_phone_is_plausible

  def number_without_prefix; ... end
  def international_prefix; ... end

  def normalized_phone_is_plausible?
    errors.add(:normalized_phone, :invalid) unless Phony.plausible?(normalized_phone)
  end
```

We want to inform the frontend user

1. If the international code is invalid first 
2. If the actual number is invalid when the international phone is valid

But when using this on the backend side / with other apps, we don't really care about this and we don't really want to see the same errors (just that the `normalized_phone` is valid or not).

So far we've been taking advantage of ActiveModel to easily serialize errors (`model.errors.map(&:errors_to_json)`). The problem is we have a different representation of the error on the frontend side (because the `phone` is serialized as 2 different attributes) and a backend/DB representation (a single "normalized_phone")

We have an edition service that is responsible for updating various user attributes including the phone and handling various draft states. Basically our main logic call behaves like this

Our logic is currently like this

```
# controller
def update
  transform_client_side_attributes_to_server_side_attributes
  edition_service.new(model, params).call() # will call amongst others model.validate after assigning new attributes
  render_json_using_activemodel_errors_for(model)
  # => 
  # { data: {...},
  #   errors: [...], # each ActiveModel error is serialized there
  # }
end

def transform_client_side_attributes_to_server_side_attributes
  international_prefix = params.xxx[:international_prefix]
  number_without_prefix = params.xxx[:number_without_prefix] 
  if valid_prefix?(international_prefix)
    if valid_number_for_prefix(number_without_prefix, international_prefix)
      params[:normalized_phone] = normalize(number_without_prefix, international_prefix)
    else
      model.errors.add(:number_without_prefix, :invalid)
    end
  else 
    model.errors.add(:international_prefix, xxx)
    return
  end
end
```

As you can see, since we have frontend specific errors, we are adding activemodel errors directly on the model as it is very convenient for serializing. The problem is, the edition_service will call at some point `model.validate` and that will have the effect of clearing other validation errors.

**Is there a way to prevent clearing errors when running validations ?** So that we could stack some validations defined on the model itself and some frontend-specific validations ?

I understand that ActiveModel might not be designed for this specific scenario, but it feels like it should be able to adapt easily.

Should I just reimplement a `model.validate_without_clearing_errors` method or maybe switch to another approach ?
items.title: Rails and activemodel errors - how to render frontend vs backend specific errors

## Your code updated:

 - Use `attrs` to return all the attributes
  - `{'class': ['lvpic', 'pic', 'img', 'left'], 'iid': '183988596953'}`

```python
def find_id(urls):
    for url in urls:
        session = requests.session()
        response = session.get(url)
        soup = BeautifulSoup(response.content, "html.parser")
        return soup.find("div", {"class": "lvpic pic img left"}).attrs['iid']

iid = find_id(urls)

print(iid)

>>> '183988596953'
```

## If you want all `iid`:

```python
def find_id(urls):
    for url in urls:
        session = requests.session()
        response = session.get(url)
        soup = BeautifulSoup(response.content, "html.parser")
        div = s.find_all("div", attrs={'class': 'lvpic pic img left'})
        return [iid.attrs['iid'] for iid in div]
```

`pop` pops an element at a particular position. If no positional arguments are used then it **removes the last element**

    ['a', 'c', 'd']

del → delete a item by id

    del my_list[1]

    ['a', 'c', 'd']

pop → remove and return item by id in list

    item = my_list.pop(1)

    ['a', 'c', 'd']
    item = 'b'
items.title: Difference between pop, del, and remove in python

answers.body_markdown:
Link layer is the electrical (or light etc) that allows two points (usually the hub/switch/router and the host) to communicate.  On top of that is the protocol such as how mac addresses are distributed, packet formats etc.

The OSI model has an opinion on how to define this as well. From:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model#Layer_architecture

```OSI model
Layer	Protocol data unit (PDU)	Function[6]
Host layers	
7	Application	Data	High-level APIs, including resource sharing, remote file access
6	Presentation	Translation of data between a networking service and an application; including character encoding, data compression and encryption/decryption
5	Session	Managing communication sessions, i.e. continuous exchange of information in the form of multiple back-and-forth transmissions between two nodes
4	Transport	Segment, Datagram	Reliable transmission of data segments between points on a network, including segmentation, acknowledgement and multiplexing
Media layers
3	Network	Packet	Structuring and managing a multi-node network, including addressing, routing and traffic control
2	Data link	Frame	Reliable transmission of data frames between two nodes connected by a physical layer
1	Physical	Symbol	Transmission and reception of raw bit streams over a physical medium
```

The Link layer is layer 2, and specifies only that bytes flow between the two nodes, but not the format of the bytes -- that's layer 3.

Some of your subsequent questions:

>Suppose you have an office with computers connected on a LAN. Why can't all the computers act as their own routers and have the office be a layer 3 topology?

You could.  This is called a Ring topology, and each node has to decide if a given packet is for "my host" or "some other host".  If it's mine, I remove it from further communication and process in the application.  If it's not mine, I send it to the next host.  It's not very efficient because you're relying on each host to process and forward, and it could take a while to have the packet reach its destination.

You still require all the other layers -- e.g. how to segregate application data from routing information etc in Layer 4.  Layers 5+ are usually application concerns (e.g. session tokens in HTML).

> Why isn't the whole internet just one big LAN?

You could logically think of it this way.  From a security and ownership point of view, though, it makes sense to segregate.  It's useful to segregate networks owned by IBM from those owned by Cisco, because IBM doesn't want their resources exposed to Cisco and vice-versa.  Also responsibilities transfer -- e.g. between ISPs ... a packet is going to go from Comcast to Google to Orange possibly and policies may need to be applied at the edge by each interested party.

> What prevents us from implementing, say, a firewall as a node in an arbitrary layer 3 topology instead of being at the interface of the network layer and the link layer?

Absolutely nothing.  However if there are other routes to the destination, a bad actor could discover that route and avoid the firewall.  So it's very common to have an air gap in the form of segregated routing.

In large network installations, this air gap can be provided by using VLAN technology, basically allowing connectivity to be restricted without providing segregated wiring.

> Why do we use different protocols (spanning trees vs. routing) to solve the same problem?

Spanning tree is a way of discovering how networks are connected to most efficiently configure routing.  So, they're not different protocols that solve the same problem, they're different network applications that support each other.
answers.title: What is the difference between the link layer and the network layer?

answers.body_markdown:
You have to imagine that you are in a cartesian coordinate system and that you are drawing lines between points in R^2 space. As soon as you figure out your origin and how circles are drawn from them, it's easy to create functions to navigate the space with ```move()``` and to actually draw something with ```draw()``` and ```circle()```. For the future, though: This is not really the place to ask broad questions like this. Anyways, here's the solution, now where's my 15 rep, kid?


```python
import turtle


def move(x,y):
    
    '''
    Sets the position of the turtle in xy coordinates.
    Automatically lifts the pen.
    '''
    turtle.pen(pendown=False)
    turtle.goto(x,y)

def draw(x,y):
    
    '''
    Same as move(), but actually draws a line.
    '''
    
    turtle.pen(pendown=True)
    turtle.goto(x,y)
    turtle.pen(pendown=False)
    
def circle(size,fill):
    
    '''
    Draws a circle of a certain size and either fills it
    or not.
    '''
    
    turtle.pen(pendown=True)
    
    if fill: 
        turtle.begin_fill()
        turtle.circle(size)
        turtle.end_fill()
    
    turtle.circle(size)


# Your coordinate system is X = [-100,100] and Y = [0,200]
# The functions move your through that coordinate system
# based on cartesian coordinates
turtle.pen(shown=False)
turtle.speed(10.5)

move(0,0)
circle(100,False)
move(50,140)
circle(10,True)
move(-50,140)
circle(10,True)
move(-70,70)
draw(0,20)
move(70,70)
draw(0,20)
move(-30,60)
draw(0,120)
move(30,60)
draw(0,120)

turtle.exitonclick()
```

There are several things you need to correct in this code.

- You cannot iterate over <code>kf</code>. You can only iterate over <code>kf.split(comm_df)</code>

- You need to somehow use the train test split that KFold provides. You are not using them in your code! The goal of the KFold is to fit your regression on the train observations, and to evaluate the regression (ie compute the RMSE in your case) on the test observations.

With this in mind, here is how I would correct your code (it is assumed here that your data is in numpy arrays, but you can easily switch to pandas)

    kf = KFold(n_splits=10)
    xval_err = 0
    for train, test in kf.split(comm_df):
        linreg.fit(comm_df[train],comm_target[train])
        p = linreg.predict(comm_df[test])
        e = p-comm_label[test]
        xval_err += np.sqrt(np.dot(e,e)/len(comm_target[test]))

    rmse_10cv = xval_err/10

answers.body_markdown:
While `*`-formatted mappings are not possible, there are certainly ways around it so you don't have to individually map each file.  One possibility is to mount the `local_directory` into the container, then create symlinks using a `for()` loop:

```
docker run -v local_directory:custom_directory other_params

answers.body_markdown:
The reason all coroutines run to completion is that you `catch` the exception thrown by job 2 within job 2 itself, so it never propagates up the hierarchy of `Job`s, so nothing happens.


However, if you remove that `catch` clause in job2, job[1-5] will always be canceled, independent of if you use `coroutineScope` or `supervisorScope`.

This is because `job2.await()` will throw the exception instead. Since this happens within the parent job of job[1-5] (i.e. within the top `coroutineScope`/`supervisorScope`), and since a failed/cancelled parent job always cancel child jobs, job[1-5] will also be cancelled.

**A1**: Use none of `coroutineScope` or `supervisorScope`, remove `coroutineScope` and put things directly under `runBlocking`.

**A2**: It certainly is allowed to catch exceptions within `async { }` to make sure it doesn't happen in `.await()` if it fits your use case.

answers.body_markdown:
This is a hard question, because today there are many options to host a website. It depends on the technology you are using to develop it.
From my experience, I would suggest two options:

**Serverless**

Pay-as-you-go rings the bell of `Serverless` to me. You will pay proportionally to the amount of requests and computer processing. (https://aws.amazon.com/serverless/).
It is recommended for SPA (if you are developing frontend with **React**, **Vue**, **Angular** or something similar), your backend will be totally detached from it. You can further choose which language to program for each endpoint you will have available (using `lambda functions`).
You can host your `frontend` in **S3** (static files of the website) and create another **S3** to be used to store uploaded/dynamic files (images and so on).

It is totally auto-scalable from the very beginning. (no requests, no pricing, except the fee for file storage in **S3**, which is very fair)


**Elastic Beanstalk**

If you have a monolith (e.g: cakephp, ruby-on-rails, django, etc.), you can use the **Elastic Beanstalk** service (https://aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/). You deploy it and set the auto-scaling criteria (e.g: latency, cpu, etc.)

**And how it applies to your question**: you want to share files between many computers assigned for the application by the auto-scaling. You can configure from the beginning to share a drive between them. This way you can handle common uploaded/dynamic/generated files easily (check this https://www.reddit.com/r/aws/comments/4szgqm/elastic_beanstalk_with_a_shared_drive_efs_as_an/ and https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/latest/dg/services-efs.html)

**Finally..**

For both cases, you will need to deal with your database server size, but AWS is providing some auto-scalling options for databases as well (**RDS** for SQL DBs). For **NoSQL** databases, there are also options for auto-scalling or just set the limits of read/write you want for the development phase and set a different one for production.

I'm sure I didn't covered all the options, you may be using something not listed above, but it covers most of the cases I have already worked with.

I hope it can help you!
answers.title: How to automatically expand disk space as required on Amazon EC2

answers.body_markdown:
Your thinking of "a server" does not match the capabilities offered by the cloud.

These days, it is best to **separate compute from database and storage**:

- Run your **compute** on Amazon EC2, or using containers or even serverless (AWS Lambda).
- Put your **database on Amazon RDS**, such as MySQL or even Amazon Aurora (which is MySQL-compatible and can auto-scale). It also takes care of backups, replication, etc.
- For **file storage** (outside of the database), use Amazon S3. For example, all of the **images** used to show homes can be served directly from S3. There is no limit to the amount of files you can store in S3. It can also handle per-user security using [Amazon S3 pre-signed URLs](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ShareObjectPreSignedURL.html).

This way, as your product matures, you can modify portions of the system (eg app) without impacting other parts. For example, you could scale across multiple servers, or move to serverless, without impacting the database or file storage systems.

Storage that is directly-attached to compute should be considered ephemeral (temporary) storage. This way, if a node fails, no data is lost. Use local storage for apps and temporary files, but not for persistent data storage. The result is that disk space really is not a consideration, since data is either stored in the database (which can auto-scale), or S3 (which has no storage limits).
answers.title: How to automatically expand disk space as required on Amazon EC2

You are using the get_parameters (plural) method, resulting in the following problems with your code:

1. The parameters are stored under the 'Parameters' key, not 'Parameter'

In order to get the value, use either the get_parameter (singular) method or do something like this to print out the names and values of the parameters requested:
```
for parameter in parameters.get('Parameters', []):
    print(parameter['Name'], '=', parameter['Value'])

answers.body_markdown:
If it is ok to load one full message at a time, this is quite simple to implement by modifying the code you posted:

    import feed_pb2 as sfeed
    import sys
    from google.protobuf.internal.encoder import _VarintBytes
    from google.protobuf.internal.decoder import _DecodeVarint32
    
    with open('/home/working/data/feed.pb', 'rb') as f:
        buf = f.read(10) # Maximum length of length prefix
        while buf:
            msg_len, new_pos = _DecodeVarint32(buf, n)
            buf = buf[new_pos:]
            # read rest of the message
            msg_buf += f.read(msg_len - len(buf))
            read_row = sfeed.standard_feed()
            read_row.ParseFromString(msg_buf)
            msg_buf = msg_buf[msg_len:]
            # do something with read_metric
            print(read_row)
            # read length prefix for next message
            buf += f.read(10 - len(buf))

This reads 10 bytes, which is enough to parse the length prefix, and then reads the rest of the message once its length is known.

String mutations are not very efficient in Python (they make a lot of copies of the data), so using `bytearray` can improve performance if your individual messages are also large.

The issue here is with the line breaks in your ```cellRendererFramework``` and ```icons``` attributes, since JSON does not support literal line breaks. If you intend to keep those attributes as strings (rather than turning the ```icons``` attribute into another object), you could try the following:

```
[ 
   { 
      "headerName":"",
      "field":"",
      "headerCheckboxSelection":true,
      "checkboxSelection":true,
      "width":45
   },
   { 
      "headerName":"A-1 PORT",
      "width":110,
      "cellRendererFramework":"params => { return this.renderCells(params) }",
      "field":"a1Port",
      "tooltipField":"A-1 PORT",
      "icons":"{ sortAscending: `<img src=${ascArrow} style=\"margin-left:65px;color:black; position:absolute\" />`, sortDescending: `<img src=${dscArrow} style=\"margin-left:65px;color:black; position:absolute\" />`}"
   }
]
```

If you want to preserve the line breaks in your string, you can insert ```\n``` wherever you want a line break.

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

I've looked at the detailed build output from both. When it generates the resources without the prefix the log shows:

> Target "CoreResGen" in file "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Professional\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets" from project "D:\Development\ipseity\src\Ipseity.Server.Repositories\Ipseity.Server.Repositories.csproj" (target "ResGen" depends on it):

answers.body_markdown:
As I pointed out in comments, most probably some of the files being sorted are modified during the sorting. Then, what was initially an old file becomes a new file _during_ sorting, thus the ordering relation 'is newer' appears non-transitive, which breaks the contract; hence the error.

IMHO you can only write your own sorting routine, which would handle such non-transitivity safely. For example it can reiterate when it detects the situation. But take care not to iterate too many times - if two or more files get updated constantly, the re-sorting routine could never finish its work!

answers.body_markdown:
According to the documentation link you provided:

> `select` returns a list of `gribmessage` instances.

So, when you do this:

    grb1=grbs.select(name='Geopotential Height')[0:24]

You are taking the result of `select` (which is a list), and then slicing that list (which yields another list). The sliced list is then bound to `grb1`. Therefore, grb1 is a list of `gribmessage` instances.

As the Pyhton exception states, a list does not have a `values` attribute. However, a single `gribmessage`, presumably, does.

Not sure if this gets you closer to the result you're expecting, but you can use a list comprehension to get the `value`s from the `gribmessage` instances in your list:

    values = [grb.values for grb in grb1]

items.body_markdown:
We are working on remodeling our user phones to separate (on the frontend) the selection of the phone international code prefix and the number without prefix.

But on the backend side, we are only storing a "normalized_phone" using the `Phony` gem

Assume an incoming payload that may contain several attributes

```json
{ user: {
  international_prefix: '+33',
  number_without_prefix: '42424242',
  last_name: 'xxx'
} }
```

and its model

```ruby
class User
  field :normalized_phone # includes both international_prefix and number_without_prefix
  field :last_name

  validate :last_name, ...
  validate :normalized_phone_is_plausible

  def number_without_prefix; ... end
  def international_prefix; ... end

  def normalized_phone_is_plausible?
    errors.add(:normalized_phone, :invalid) unless Phony.plausible?(normalized_phone)
  end
```

We want to inform the frontend user

1. If the international code is invalid first 
2. If the actual number is invalid when the international phone is valid

But when using this on the backend side / with other apps, we don't really care about this and we don't really want to see the same errors (just that the `normalized_phone` is valid or not).

So far we've been taking advantage of ActiveModel to easily serialize errors (`model.errors.map(&:errors_to_json)`). The problem is we have a different representation of the error on the frontend side (because the `phone` is serialized as 2 different attributes) and a backend/DB representation (a single "normalized_phone")

We have an edition service that is responsible for updating various user attributes including the phone and handling various draft states. Basically our main logic call behaves like this

Our logic is currently like this

```
# controller
def update
  transform_client_side_attributes_to_server_side_attributes
  edition_service.new(model, params).call() # will call amongst others model.validate after assigning new attributes
  render_json_using_activemodel_errors_for(model)
  # => 
  # { data: {...},
  #   errors: [...], # each ActiveModel error is serialized there
  # }
end

def transform_client_side_attributes_to_server_side_attributes
  international_prefix = params.xxx[:international_prefix]
  number_without_prefix = params.xxx[:number_without_prefix] 
  if valid_prefix?(international_prefix)
    if valid_number_for_prefix(number_without_prefix, international_prefix)
      params[:normalized_phone] = normalize(number_without_prefix, international_prefix)
    else
      model.errors.add(:number_without_prefix, :invalid)
    end
  else 
    model.errors.add(:international_prefix, xxx)
    return
  end
end
```

As you can see, since we have frontend specific errors, we are adding activemodel errors directly on the model as it is very convenient for serializing. The problem is, the edition_service will call at some point `model.validate` and that will have the effect of clearing other validation errors.

**Is there a way to prevent clearing errors when running validations ?** So that we could stack some validations defined on the model itself and some frontend-specific validations ?

I understand that ActiveModel might not be designed for this specific scenario, but it feels like it should be able to adapt easily.

Should I just reimplement a `model.validate_without_clearing_errors` method or maybe switch to another approach ?
items.title: Rails and activemodel errors - how to render frontend vs backend specific errors

answers.body_markdown:
Link layer is the electrical (or light etc) that allows two points (usually the hub/switch/router and the host) to communicate.  On top of that is the protocol such as how mac addresses are distributed, packet formats etc.

The OSI model has an opinion on how to define this as well. From:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model#Layer_architecture

```OSI model
Layer	Protocol data unit (PDU)	Function[6]
Host layers	
7	Application	Data	High-level APIs, including resource sharing, remote file access
6	Presentation	Translation of data between a networking service and an application; including character encoding, data compression and encryption/decryption
5	Session	Managing communication sessions, i.e. continuous exchange of information in the form of multiple back-and-forth transmissions between two nodes
4	Transport	Segment, Datagram	Reliable transmission of data segments between points on a network, including segmentation, acknowledgement and multiplexing
Media layers
3	Network	Packet	Structuring and managing a multi-node network, including addressing, routing and traffic control
2	Data link	Frame	Reliable transmission of data frames between two nodes connected by a physical layer
1	Physical	Symbol	Transmission and reception of raw bit streams over a physical medium
```

The Link layer is layer 2, and specifies only that bytes flow between the two nodes, but not the format of the bytes -- that's layer 3.

Some of your subsequent questions:

>Suppose you have an office with computers connected on a LAN. Why can't all the computers act as their own routers and have the office be a layer 3 topology?

You could.  This is called a Ring topology, and each node has to decide if a given packet is for "my host" or "some other host".  If it's mine, I remove it from further communication and process in the application.  If it's not mine, I send it to the next host.  It's not very efficient because you're relying on each host to process and forward, and it could take a while to have the packet reach its destination.

You still require all the other layers -- e.g. how to segregate application data from routing information etc in Layer 4.  Layers 5+ are usually application concerns (e.g. session tokens in HTML).

> Why isn't the whole internet just one big LAN?

You could logically think of it this way.  From a security and ownership point of view, though, it makes sense to segregate.  It's useful to segregate networks owned by IBM from those owned by Cisco, because IBM doesn't want their resources exposed to Cisco and vice-versa.  Also responsibilities transfer -- e.g. between ISPs ... a packet is going to go from Comcast to Google to Orange possibly and policies may need to be applied at the edge by each interested party.

> What prevents us from implementing, say, a firewall as a node in an arbitrary layer 3 topology instead of being at the interface of the network layer and the link layer?

Absolutely nothing.  However if there are other routes to the destination, a bad actor could discover that route and avoid the firewall.  So it's very common to have an air gap in the form of segregated routing.

In large network installations, this air gap can be provided by using VLAN technology, basically allowing connectivity to be restricted without providing segregated wiring.

> Why do we use different protocols (spanning trees vs. routing) to solve the same problem?

Spanning tree is a way of discovering how networks are connected to most efficiently configure routing.  So, they're not different protocols that solve the same problem, they're different network applications that support each other.
answers.title: What is the difference between the link layer and the network layer?

answers.body_markdown:
You have to imagine that you are in a cartesian coordinate system and that you are drawing lines between points in R^2 space. As soon as you figure out your origin and how circles are drawn from them, it's easy to create functions to navigate the space with ```move()``` and to actually draw something with ```draw()``` and ```circle()```. For the future, though: This is not really the place to ask broad questions like this. Anyways, here's the solution, now where's my 15 rep, kid?


```python
import turtle


def move(x,y):
    
    '''
    Sets the position of the turtle in xy coordinates.
    Automatically lifts the pen.
    '''
    turtle.pen(pendown=False)
    turtle.goto(x,y)

def draw(x,y):
    
    '''
    Same as move(), but actually draws a line.
    '''
    
    turtle.pen(pendown=True)
    turtle.goto(x,y)
    turtle.pen(pendown=False)
    
def circle(size,fill):
    
    '''
    Draws a circle of a certain size and either fills it
    or not.
    '''
    
    turtle.pen(pendown=True)
    
    if fill: 
        turtle.begin_fill()
        turtle.circle(size)
        turtle.end_fill()
    
    turtle.circle(size)


# Your coordinate system is X = [-100,100] and Y = [0,200]
# The functions move your through that coordinate system
# based on cartesian coordinates
turtle.pen(shown=False)
turtle.speed(10.5)

move(0,0)
circle(100,False)
move(50,140)
circle(10,True)
move(-50,140)
circle(10,True)
move(-70,70)
draw(0,20)
move(70,70)
draw(0,20)
move(-30,60)
draw(0,120)
move(30,60)
draw(0,120)

turtle.exitonclick()
```

There are several things you need to correct in this code.

- You need to somehow use the train test split that KFold provides. You are not using them in your code! The goal of the KFold is to fit your regression on the train observations, and to evaluate the regression (ie compute the RMSE in your case) on the test observations.

With this in mind, here is how I would correct your code (it is assumed here that your data is in numpy arrays, but you can easily switch to pandas)

    kf = KFold(n_splits=10)
    xval_err = 0
    for train, test in kf.split(comm_df):
        linreg.fit(comm_df[train],comm_target[train])
        p = linreg.predict(comm_df[test])
        e = p-comm_label[test]
        xval_err += np.sqrt(np.dot(e,e)/len(comm_target[test]))

    rmse_10cv = xval_err/10

answers.body_markdown:
While `*`-formatted mappings are not possible, there are certainly ways around it so you don't have to individually map each file.  One possibility is to mount the `local_directory` into the container, then create symlinks using a `for()` loop:

```
docker run -v local_directory:custom_directory other_params
for i in `ls local_directory/*py`
do
  docker exec -it ln -s custom_directory/${i} docker_directory <container_name>
done
```

answers.body_markdown:
The reason all coroutines run to completion is that you `catch` the exception thrown by job 2 within job 2 itself, so it never propagates up the hierarchy of `Job`s, so nothing happens.


However, if you remove that `catch` clause in job2, job[1-5] will always be canceled, independent of if you use `coroutineScope` or `supervisorScope`.

This is because `job2.await()` will throw the exception instead. Since this happens within the parent job of job[1-5] (i.e. within the top `coroutineScope`/`supervisorScope`), and since a failed/cancelled parent job always cancel child jobs, job[1-5] will also be cancelled.

**A1**: Use none of `coroutineScope` or `supervisorScope`, remove `coroutineScope` and put things directly under `runBlocking`.

**A2**: It certainly is allowed to catch exceptions within `async { }` to make sure it doesn't happen in `.await()` if it fits your use case.

When this happens, gpg looks in keychain, finds the "default default" key (meaning the one it would choose without `--default-key`) and tries to sign with that one.

This results in a password prompt, which halts the script, because that key is encrypted. (I'm expecting one that is not encrypted, because this is a toy prototype.)

How do I make gpg give up if it can't find the specified key?

How do I make it give up if the key is encrypted and it can't be used without a password?
items.title: How to prevent gpg from choosing fallback secret key, when --default-key is not found?

Link model has:

    public function infos()

}

Info model has:

        return $this->belongsTo('link');

The dashboard has a controller.

```
$linksByOwner = Link::where('user_id',$user_id)->get();

Now i'm trying to reach the info that's nestled in the Link. I tried this using:
```
    $collectedData = $linksByOwner->infos(); < Not working
    $collectedData = Info::where('link_id',19)->info(); < Not working

    dd($collectedData);

This gave me the following error:

both models have a foreign key connected to them in the database migration

 $table->foreign('link_id')
                ->references('id')->on('links')
                ->onDelete('cascade');

Could someone show or tell me how I could fix this? Is it a scoping error? Do I need to connect the classes differently?

items.body_markdown:
I have a specific use case. Alice issues a transaction to Bob. Bob can deal with this in a number of ways (accept, reject, settle). So far so good. 

However, in this scenario Bob can also take the original transaction and generate his own transaction based on this to Carol and Dave. Essentially, if Alice claims $10, Bob can say that Carol should pay $2, Dave $3 and Bob will pay the $5. 

Dave could then say that Eve should pay $1 of his share. 

Much, but not all,  of the data on the original tx is repeated across the subsequent tx. Some information is not to be shared, ie the original value of $10 should not be known to Eve. Carol and Dave do not know what each other is paying. 

There are some complications. If Alice decides to cancel the claim, the cancellation verification code needs to check that the TX to Carol and Dave are also cancelled, otherwise Bob would end up with money he is not entitled to when they settle. 

Also, commercially, the sums of the TX that Bob generate can exceed the amount Alice is claiming from him. 

I know this is complex, but does can anyone offer me a clue bat as to where to start?
items.title: Linked Transactions - looking for clues
